The conclusion which emerges is that no action can be in the least effective if drug abuse is considered as a single epidemic disease to be treated by standardized therapeutic or prophylactic measures comparable to those used in tuberculosis control or the prevention of rickets. The failure of the efforts made in this field by neighbouring countries, however well-funded and ingenious they may have been, is sufficient to prove this point. The diversity of the cases we have studied has led us to agree with the clinicians that the habitual use of drugs is, in most cases, the symptom of a complex personal and social "pathology", in addition to being a means of relief, escape or change for the young person concerned. Fundamentally, except in regard to the risks involved, there is little difference here from the situation which may be observed in the case of all those persons who are legally misusing tranquillizers and sleeping pills. Clinical studies, which are obviously indispensable in investigating any human problem, have long emphasized the complexity of the factors involved.
